awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Extension of a Dendrochronological Sequence to Northern Mesoamerica
awd_abstract_narration:
Drs. Paula Turkon, Sturt Manning, and Carol Griggs, along with colleagues from Mexico, will conduct research to provide a high-resolution absolute tree-ring chronology for Northern Mesoamerican archaeological sites using a combination of tree-ring and AMS radiocarbon data.  This project extends their preliminary research both geographically and chronologically, with the goal of linking the existing Epiclassic chronology from Northwestern Mesoamerica that ends in the 8th century A.D., to the regionally extensive, calendar-dated chronologies from living and relic trees in the same region. The dendrochronological results will offer dating precision to archaeologists working in these regions for time periods that do not have written sources of chronological data. It will also establish the foundation for climate reconstruction studies that, in the future, will help clarify the long-term relationships between the magnitude of climatic change and human response. In fostering close collaboration between archaeologists, dendrochronologists, graduate, and undergraduate students from multiple institutions throughout Mexico and the United States, this project's mission is to encourage the application of dendroarchaeology [=archaeological dendrochronology], currently not part of archaeological fieldwork or analysis in Mexico. 

Mesoamerican archaeologists have long acknowledged the need for precise dating methods in order to understand cultural change, particularly in the region north of the core of Mesoamerican culture. Yet despite tremendous success in the development of tree-ring dating of archaeological sites just north in the American Southwest, and the more recent development of long tree-ring chronologies in Mexico that cover the past 1300 years, dendroarchaeology has been virtually absent in Mesoamerica. The first stage of this NSF funded project demonstrated the availability, measurability, and similarities in growth patterns ("crossdatability") of archaeological tree-ring samples in Northwestern Mesoamerica from the 5th to 8th centuries A.D.  In this second stage, the researchers will incorporate archaeological samples from Postclassic and historic sites located in a broader geographic region in northern Mesoamerica. Because the new archaeological collections of wood will likewise be from a time period for which there are no well-established master chronologies, the tree-ring sequences produced from the prehispanic sites will be initially anchored in time by "radiocarbon wiggle-matching."   This method fits a known relative sequence of radiocarbon dates from specific tree-rings against the radiocarbon calibration curve to achieve a precise fit and thus calendar placement with minimal error.  Ultimately, we intend to create a continuous tree-ring record from the present back to the Classic period, using both the archaeological and historic collections, as well as existing calendar-dated chronologies.  The resulting data will not only fill a significant gap in our knowledge of the chronology of Northern Mesoamerica, but help address broader questions such as the rate, timing, and directionality of cultural influences with the Mesoamerican cultural core. Since dendroarchaeological methods are cumulative and iterative, the chronologies will gain in length, sample depth, and robustness, and will become increasingly useful to archaeologists working in broader geographic regions and time periods.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

OUTCOMES: Collaborative Research: Dendroarchaeology in Northern Mesoamerica from A.D. 500 to Present

Political and climatic instability are the most frequently cited reasons for the cultural transformations that occurred in Northwestern Mesoamerica during the Classic and Postclassic periods. Yet there are no precise chronological controls to pinpoint the direction of political and cultural relationships, nor are there high-resolution climatic reconstructions for this region and period to assess the variability of climate over space and time. To address this deficiency, the objective of this project (#1755504) was to work towards providing a high-resolution absolute tree-ring chronology for Northern Mesoamerican archaeological sites using a combination of tree-ring and AMS radiocarbon data.  This project extends our preliminary research both geographically and chronologically, with the goal of linking the existing Epiclassic chronology from Northwestern Mesoamerica that ends in the 8th century A.D., to the regionally extensive, calendar-dated chronologies from living and relic trees in the same region.

Over the duration of this grant, the team assembled 164 samples from 14 historic and two Postclassic sites in northwestern Mexico. Analysis was completed through a multi-institutional collaboration between Ithaca College, Cornell University Tree-Ring Laboratory, the Instituto Nacional de Antropología e Historia, and the Tree Ring Laboratory at the Instituto Nacional de Investigaciones Forestales, Agrícolas y Pecuarias (INIFAP). The historic collections results (A.D. 1400-1925) extend prior regional dendrochronological sequences. (See Table 1 and Figure 1 for context and date ranges for each site.) AMS wiggle-match analysis was conducted for the two floating sequences from the Postclassic sites of Cueva de Maguey, Durango and Tula, Hidalgo (10-12th centuries A.D.).  In addition to the work on the new sites, and because the impact of the prehispanic sites has high stakes due to the age and limited alternative dating methods, we continued ring-sequence development and 14C wiggle-match anchoring of floating sequences previously collected from the Epiclassic sites of El Coporo, and the Ciudadela of La Quemada (#1324106), both of which dated to the late 7th century A.D. Together, these studies made significant progress toward filling gaps in tree-ring sequence between the 8-16th centuries A.D. (Figure 2).

Due to limited chronological precision in Northwestern Mesoamerica, archaeologists tend to address questions relating to interaction and social identification within and between sites using material culture, primarily using ceramic assemblages and frequencies to demonstrate a stylistic influence.  While these studies provide relative chronological relationships, they are only able to provide general date ranges.  In order to refine these date spans, we collaborated with Drs. Ben Nelson and Andrea Torvinen from the La Quemada/Malpaso Valley project to use Bayesian based statistical analyses of annual plant AMS and tree-ring dates to chronologically define these phases.  Our preliminary results show that the ceramic phases are considerably shorter than previously proposed (Figure 3).

In anticipation of future climate reconstruction studies to address questions between environmental conditions and culture change in northwestern Mesoamerica, we undertook two separate pilot projects to compare tree-ring width, instrumental meteorological data, and isotopic data, with the objective to determine the environmental factors that influence tree-ring growth (Zacatecas and Durango). Both projects independently identified marginal rainy season months as critical for tree-ring growth, strong indications that ring-width variability may, with further work, provide some indication of precipitation levels for time periods that lack instrumental data.  The resulting data have the potential to address climate focused hypotheses regarding the development and dissolution of the prehispanic cultures, especially during the Epiclassic period.

While these studies made significant contributions to the goals of tree-ring sequence development and climate reconstruction, there is much work left to be done.  Outreach is therefore critical for the continuation of dendrochronological analysis in Mexico.  With the exception of this project, dendroarchaeological applications are absent in Mexico, partly because knowledge of this methodology and evidence of its potential to address research questions is limited.  For this reason, part of our mission was to offer workshops and presentations to demonstrate the principles and possibilities of dendroarchaeological analysis.

Providing a continuous, archaeologically relevant tree-ring chronology in Mexico from the Classic Period to the present is a critical step in understanding long-term patterns of climatic change, an issue very much in the forefront of public interest, policy, and debate. For the general public, dendroarchaeological data are integral to examining human responses to climate change from a long-term perspective and can significantly add to discussions about the effects of modern climatic change. For archaeologists working throughout Mesoamerica, the high-resolution chronologies and foundation for climate reconstruction studies will revolutionize the precision with which they can examine cultural changes and their relationship to environmental conditions.
